review.title: On how percolation threshold affects PSO performance
review.abstract: Statistical evidence of the influence of neighborhood topology on the performance of particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithms has been shown in many works. However, little has been done about the implications could have the percolation threshold in determining the topology of this neighborhood. This work addresses this problem for individuals that, like robots, are able to sense in a limited neighborhood around them. Based on the concept of percolation threshold, and more precisely, the disk percolation model in 2D, we show that better results are obtained for low values of radius, when individuals occasionally ask others their best visited positions, with the consequent decrease of computational complexity. On the other hand, since percolation threshold is a universal measure, it could have a great interest to compare the performance of different hybrid PSO algorithms.

metadata.title: On how percolation threshold affects PSO performance

sections.text: ar Xiv: 120 4.38 44v1 [cs.AI] April 17 2Keywords: Particle Swarm Optimization parameters, Percolation Theory, Hybrid PSO.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This theory is particularly well adapted to describe global physical properties such as the connectivity and conductivity behavior of geometrically complex systems. This paper analyzes the role of the percolation threshold, a universal measure of connectivity in graphs, to analyze the convergence of swarm algorithms as a function of the expected number of neighbors in the initial phase, and therefore to develop a framework to compare the performance of hybrid PSO algorithms. Analysis of the performance of different hybrid PSO algorithms has been addressed in various papers [4,7,3]. However, in this work we focus on the concept of the percolation threshold as a useful tool to define the parameter space for which the performance of the basic PSO algorithms is improved.

sections.heading: 2 Analysis of goals as a function of the expected degree at initial step.
sections.text: Applied equation (2), we examine the success of the PSO algorithm as a function of radius R (a) after a longitudinal study of the expected mean degree. - Dataset A: 0.000 ≤ a ≤ 0.9, which means that only a fraction of individuals have a better neighborhood: from 0.0 to 0.9 with the maximum range of 0.1. Table 1 shows the corresponding neighborhood radius R (a). Each function is performed 20 times, so that for each R (a) 100 runs have been completed. - Dataset B: 1 ≤ a ≤ 30, from the minimum (1 neighbor) to the maximum (29 neighbors) plus one, 30 neighbors with step 1. Neighborhood radius R varies in the interval 20,601 ≤ R ≤ 112,838. - Best global value register at each run the best position that each agent remembers is the best global − f (t).

sections.heading: 3 Exploring the disk percolation threshold
sections.text: The values of R around the critical radius Rc were examined in varying degrees along the interval. [4,37, 4,515] just before the critical threshold ac = 4,512 with step 0.001. Therefore, R (a) varies in the interval [43.066, 43.775] in intervals of 0.01. Each instance of parameter R was executed 100 times, 20 for each function fi. Table 3 shows the means of the goals, the best global value achieved and final step. Compared to Table 2, the total number of successful runs corresponds to the goals of Dataset A, 88.5%, as well as the mean global value, 0.02. The difference to Dataset A lies in the number of steps: at critical radius Rc the performance of the PSO algorithm decreases to the mean of 42 iterations in successful runs, close to the 38 steps achieved in Dataset B. Mean steps, 197, are only in the middle of the 199 dataset S4. As a large dataset B = 4.5B. As a neighbor, S4 is the result of Sollset Sc.

sections.heading: 5 Comparing different domain through degree a.
sections.text: Experiments in previous sections were performed on the same domain conditions of f0 and f6: xmax = 100, S = 200. The theory of plate leakage gives us a way to relate the expected number of neighbors a to the neighboring radius R of individuals, despite different parameter values of the world, population P, and square side S. In Table 6, we give values of R for different degrees a1 = 0.00151, a2 = 0.8, a3 = 29, and for a critical radius ac = 4.512, calculated according to (2). Table 6 shows that the conditions xmax = 100 = S 2 and P = 30 for each yield a corresponding radius R (a) in the intervals examined in previous sections: R (0.00151) = 0.8 [0.75, 0.9] analyzed in section 4, R (0.8) = 18.426 in datasets A and R (29) = 110.941 in datasets B of section 2 and critical radius R = 0.9].

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we show that the infiltration threshold is a tool for analyzing the convergence of swarms in relation to the expected number of neighbors in a first step. While the traditional PSO algorithm is based on the external calculation of the world's best convergence target, we present experiments here that suggest that, on the one hand, very small amounts of information translated into very low values of a are sufficient to provoke the convergence of PSO swarms. Furthermore, better values of convergence are found. On the other hand, a low degree ac = 4.512 is sufficient for both purposes: convergence to the minimum and to small runs. The steps required for convergence become constant from this critical value. Therefore, more neighbors do the same than ac neighbors. The infiltration threshold of disks is a measure of 2D systems. Efforts are being made to investigate the calculation of the infiltration thresholds for higher dimensions.

Velocity vi (t+ 1) is a randomized linear combination of three forces: (i) inertia, weighted by parameter w ∈ [0, 1], (ii) the personal attraction c1 to the position pi where the minimum value of a function f (pi) was found, and (iii) the social attraction to the position pgi of the best goal remembered by the neighbors of individual i in a given topology.

Some authors [12,14] have carried out social network statistical studies to address the effects of neighborhood topology in PSO algorithms, concluding that the topology used conditions strongly the convergence of these algorithms.
